description:
Thamnophis sirtalis, commonly known as the common garter snake, is a widespread species of snake native to North America. It belongs to the genus Thamnophis, which are commonly referred to as garter snakes.

The common garter snake is a medium-sized snake, typically ranging from 46 to 137 cm (18 to 54 inches) in length. It has a slender, cylindrical body with a distinct head and a tapering tail. The snake's coloration is variable, with a typical pattern of three longitudinal stripes, usually yellow or green, running along the length of its body. The background color can range from brown to black, olive, or even reddish.

Thamnophis sirtalis is known for its adaptability and can be found in a variety of habitats, including meadows, woodlands, suburban areas, and even in proximity to human settlements. It is an active, diurnal snake that primarily feeds on small rodents, amphibians, and invertebrates.

The common garter snake is an ectothermic, or cold-blooded, animal, and it relies on environmental temperature to regulate its body temperature. It is an important component of the ecosystem, serving as both a predator and prey, and plays a role in the natural control of small mammal and amphibian populations.
